review.title: Object-Oriented Bayesian Networks
review.abstract: Bayesian networks provide a modeling language and the associated stochastic domain inference algorithm, and have been successfully applied in a variety of medium-sized applications. However, in this paper we describe an object-oriented Bayesian network language (OOBN) that allows complex domains to be described with respect to interconnected objects. We use a Bayesian network fragment to describe the probabilistic relationships between the attributes of an object. These attributes can themselves be objects and provide a natural framework for encoding parts of hierarchies. Classes are used to provide a reusable probabilistic model that can be applied to several similar objects. Classes also support the inheritance of model fragments of a class to a subclass, allowing the common aspects of related classes to be defined only once. Our language has a clear declarative sequence: an OBabilistic object can be uniformly interpreted within an OBabilistic model as a structural element that can be used as such.

metadata.abstractText: Bayesian networks provide a modeling language and associated inference algorithm for stochastic domains. They have been successfully applied in a variety of medium-scale applications. However, when faced with a large complex domain, the task of modeling using Bayesian networks begins to resemble the task of pro­ gramming using logical circuits. In this paper, we de­ scribe an object-oriented Bayesian network (OOBN) lan­ guage, which allows complex domains to be described in terms of inter-related objects. We use a Bayesian net­ work fragment to describe the probabilistic relations be­ tween the attributes of an object. These attributes can themselves be objects, providing a natural framework for encoding part-of hierarchies. Classes are used to pro­ vide a reusable probabilistic model which can be applied to multiple similar objects. Classes also support inher­ itance of model fragments from a class to a subclass, allowing the common aspects of related classes to be defined only once. Our language has clear declarative semantics: an OOBN can be interpreted as a stochas­ tic functional program, so that it uniquely specifies a probabilistic model. We provide an inference algorithm for OOBNs, and show that much of the structural infor­ mation encoded by an OOBN-particularly the encap­ sulation of variables within an object and the reuse of model fragments in different contexts--can also be used to speed up the inference process.
